Born on June 26, 1993, in Boca Raton, Florida, Ariana Grande began her career as a young girl, participating in various television and theater productions.

Her first step towards stardom was in the eighth season of NBC's popular teen drama, "America's Got Talent," where she impressed the audience and judges with her powerful vocals. In 2010, she landed a role in the Nickelodeon series, "Victorious," playing the character Cat Valentine. The show was a massive success and catapulted her into the limelight, as she also co-wrote several songs that were featured on its soundtrack.

In 2012, Ariana released her self-titled debut album, "Ariana Grande," which included the popular singles "7 Rings," "The Way," and "Problem." The following year, she became the face of several high-profile brands, including Target and OPI Nails, which further increased her popularity.

Grande's career continued to evolve, and in 2014, she starred in the TV series "Scream Queens" alongside Jamie Lee Curtis and Emma Roberts. She also released her second studio album, "My Everything," in 2014, featuring hit songs like "Problem" and "Break Free," the latter of which featured rapper Zedd.

In 2015, Ariana announced her partnership with RCA Records and released her third studio album, "Dangerous Woman," which included the popular singles "Into You" and "Side to Side." The album showcased her versatility as a performer, featuring genres like R&B, pop, and hip hop.

In 2016, Grande starred in the blockbuster film "The Greatest Showman," in which she sang the title song and played the role of Anne Wheeler. The following year, she released her fourth studio album, "Sweetener," which was met with critical acclaim and commercial success.
